description.narrative: Målet för UNU-WIDERs verksamhet är att genom god forskning och aktiv policypåverkan bidra till en samhällsomvandling som i sin tur bidrar till de globala utvecklingsmålen och ökar människors välbefinnande i låg- och lägre medelinkomstländer. Denna forskning och policypåverkan fångas i arbetsprogrammet för perioden 2019-23 i tre teman: "Transforming economies, states, and societies. Creating and sharing knowledge for development", vilka beskrivs något utförligare nedan. 2019-23 års arbetsprogram UNU-WIDERs nya arbetsprogram bygger vidare på tidigare arbetsprogram, men knyter också tematiskt an till Agenda 2030 för hållbar utveckling, genom att mobilisera policyrelevant forskning och aktiviteter kring ett urval av agendans målområden. UNU-WIDERs gamla arbetsprogram fångades i tre teman under vilka rymdes ett antal forskningsprojekt. Enligt den senaste årsrapporten (2018) sorterades 10 projekt under "transformation", sex under "inclusion" och två under "sustainability". Fyra av dessa projekt, som rymts under temat "transformation", följer med in i det nya arbetsprogrammet: "Inclusive growth in Mozambique"; "Towards inclusive development in Myanmar", "SA-TIED - Southern Africa - towards inclusive economic development" samt det nyaste projektet från 2018: "Supporting evidece-based decision making in Tanzania and beyond". Av titlarna att döma ter sig insorteringen under "transformation" lite konstlad (det finns flera projekt om inkludering men dessa återfinns inte under temat "inclusion"), vilket förmodligen illustrerar behovet av att stöpa om programmet inför den nya fasen. Arbetsprogrammet för 2019-23 tar fasta på transformationsanslaget i det gamla programmet genom att ta sig an tre transformativa teman som alla syftar till att förstå den omvandling som krävs för att skapa inkluderande och hållbara samhällen. 1) "Transforming economies" handlar om de storskaliga ekonomiska omvandlingar som måste till för att den absoluta fattigdomen liksom ojämlika ekonomiska och sociala förhållanden ska minska. Man pekar på den omfattande omvandlingen av ekonomierna i Asien under senare år, samtidigt som utvecklingen i Latinamerika varit ojämn och Afrika har halkat efter, om än med variation (vilket bland annat forskning inom det förra arbetsprogrammet visat). Strukturomvandling krävs för att öka fattiga länders skattebas och därmed öka de skatteintäkter som krävs för sociala, infrastruktur- och miljömässiga investeringar för en hållbar tillväxt. Temat knyter an till flera tidigare UNU-WIDER-projekt, inte minst de som handlat om förändringar mot mer gröna energislag ("the political economy of clean energy transitions"). Forskningsområden inom detta block rymmer ämnen som informalitet, sysselsättningsskapande, utmaningarna i den globala ekonomin, frågor om bistånd och globala kollektiva varor, ICT och automatisering, och hur data och information kan bistå i politikens utformining. 2) "Transforming states" fokuserar på statens förmåga (och oförmåga) att driva på en utveckling mot inkluderande och hållbara samhällen. Den privata (jobbskapande) sektorns möjligheter är beroende av kapabla stater med rimliga regelverk och förmåga att tillhandahålla kollektiva varor och annan service. Men för detta krävs förståelse för hur politiken slår, för beskattning och för statens budgetering. I detta block ryms bland annat analys av offentliga utgifter, av skatteupptag i olika inkomst- och företagsgrupper, hur staten ska hantera marknadsmisslyckanden med mera. UNU-WIDER har i tilltagande grad utvecklat projekt där man samarbetar med förvaltningar och forskare bland annat för att utveckla modeller som till exempel simulerar olika typer av skattepolitik, och för framtagande och underhåll av databaser. En sådan är Global Revenue Dataset (GDR), en databas som möjliggör jämförelser av skatteintäkter mellan länder och som ursprungligen tagits fram av forskarnätverket International Centre for Tax and Development (ICTD) och som nu förvaltas av UNU-WIDER. 3) "Transforming societies" handlar om den samhällsstruktur som blir resultatet av politiska beslut och ekonomisk utveckling, men också de samhälleliga förutsättningar som sätter gränser för utvecklingen. Arbetsprogrammet talar bland annat om vikten av kapacitet för att analysera data som följer upp den sociala förändring som sker till följd av interna politiska beslut men också av annan påverkan. Såväl möjligheter till social förändring som risker med dessa skeenden är viktiga delar här. Forskningsfrågor inom området handlar om empowerment (jämställdhet, minskad ojämlikhet, minskad fattigdom), inklusive kapacitetsbyggande för att mäta och följa upp förändringen i data, därtill vilken roll det sociala kapitalet spelar för att stärka relationer och minska risker, samt migration, både som en möjlighet men också som resultat av fattigdom, miljöförstöring och konflikter. UNU-WIDERs World Income Inequaility Database (WIID), en av de mest fullständiga databaserna för inkomstojämlikhet. Den lanserades i sin första version 2000, den uppdateras kontinuerligt (nuvarande version är den fjärde och kom i december 2018) och är i detta sammanhang en viktig resurs för forskningsprojekten. I arbetsprogrammet identifieras tre områden som ska genomsyra arbetet ("cross-cutting concerns"), nämligen 1) att reducera fragilitet/sårbarhet och risk; 2) att stärka fattiga och marginaliserade människors, inklusive kvinnors och flickors, egenmakt (empowerment); och 3) att bidra till kunskap och kapacitet, särskilt vad gäller policyåtgärder. Kanaler för UNU-WIDERs arbete UNU-WIDERs forskning ska bidra till en samhällsomvandling som ökar människors välbefinnande i låg- och lägre medelinkomstländer vilket bidrar till att de globala utvecklingsmålen nås. Detta ska åstadkommas genom tre kanaler. Den första är utvecklingsrelevant forskning. De forskningsfrågor som ingår i de tre transformationer som uttrycks i arbetsprogrammet antyder vad detta handlar om: informalitet, sysselsättning/jobbskapande, effekter av den globala ekonomin, den globala arkitekturen för bistånd och kollektiva nyttigheter, effekter av ICT/automation, robusta system för offentliga utgifter, skattefrågor, kompensation för marknadsmisslyckanden, hantering av naturresurser, egenmakt för att nå sociala mål, socialt kapital och migration. De databaser som UNU-WIDER etablerat och vidareutvecklar, till exempel World Income Inequality Database (WIID), är ett av instrumenten för att genomföra denna forskning. Den andra kanalen är kapacitetsutveckling. För detta har UNU-WIDER flera verktyg. Ett är strategiska institutionella partnerskap med ett urval institutioner och nätverk i låg- och lägre medelinkomstländer, där forskare och funktionärer i offentlig förvaltning (finansministerier, centralbanker etc) genom UNU-WIDERs arrangemang visar upp egen forskning eller presenterar relevanta policyfrågor som behöver utforskas. För dessa sammanhang utformar UNU-WIDER olika tekniska specialkurser, till exempel i utveckling och användning av skattesimuleringsmodeller. Under 2018 deltog 475 personer i de 13 korta specialkurser som gavs, varav 458 var hemmahörande i låginkomstländer. Ett annat kapacitetsstärkande verktyg är att involvera forskare från låg- och lägre medelinkomstländer i UNU-WIDERs forskningsprojekt. Av de 190 UNU-WIDER working papers som publicerades 2018 (och som omfattar en stor del av forskningsproduktionen vid UNU-WIDER) hade 63 procent en forskare från ett låginkomstland som medförfattare (50 procent av papperen hade en kvinna som medförfattare och 34 procent en kvinna från ett låginkomstland). Ytterligare ett verktyg är de gästplatser vid institutet i Helsingfors som programmet erbjuder dels doktorander, dels mer seniora forskare. Sedan 2001 har UNU-WIDER tagit emot 267 forskare från hela det samhällsvetenskapliga fältet, med tonvikt på nationalekonomer. Bara 3 procent av de som söker dessa platser tas emot av UNU-WIDER. En kortlista på de mest lämpliga tas fram på basis av explicita kriterier (bland annat rörande inriktning och kvalitet på forskningsprojektet och kandidatens meriter), varefter institutets forskningspersonal (faculty) slutgiltigt väljer. Av de 22 forskare som tillbringade tid i Helsingfors under 2018 var 20 från låg ooch lägre medelinkomständer och nio var kvinnor (gästforskarna kom från Argentina, Brasilien, Kamerun, Kina, Etiopien, Tyskland, Ghana, Indien (tre personer), Indonesia, Kenya, Malysia, Mexico, Korea, Togo, Uganda och Storbritannien). UNU-WIDER har också sedan 2014 samarbetat med University of Ghana i en forskarutbildning inom utvecklingsekonomi, med hittills 31 doktorander, där de första tre doktoranderna disputerat i början av 2019. Detta samarbete kommer dock att gradvis avslutas i sin nuvarande form (de kvarvarande knappa trettiotalet doktorander kommer att avsluta sina studier), eftersom finansieringen varit mer problematisk än förväntat. UNU-WIDER har under en sjuårsperiod bidragit till detta program med totalt 1,3 miljoner USD. Återstående finansiering fram till 2020 syftar till att särställa doktorandernas utbildning. Forskningsförmedling och policypåverkan är den tredje kanalen för UNU-WIDER. Organisationen definierar olika grupper som sin huvudpublik: 1) beslutsfattare i utvecklingsländer; 2) biståndsgivare (development partners); 3) den globala forskningsvärlden, inklusive FN-systemet. Organisationen har en ganska omfattande erfarenhet av och nätverk inom alla dessa tre målgrupper och man söker presentera forskningsresultat och debattera dess implikationer. Kommunikationen sker bland annat genom aktiv dialog vid olika ministerier, lokala grupperingar och i andra sammanhang i direkt anslutning till att forskningsprojekt genomförs och presenteras. Dessutom organiserar UNU-WIDER regelbundet större allmänna utvecklingsforskningskonferenser, liksom mer tematiska evenemang. UNU-WIDER har också en omfattande publikationsverksamhet med en kollegialt granskad working paper series samt bokproduktion. Organisationen har en relativt ny hemsida där alla egna publikationer finns tillgängliga för alla.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNU-WIDER (World Institute for Development Economics Research) är ett forsknings- och utbildningsinstitut grundat 1984, med säte i Helsingfors. Verksamheten finansieras genom en kapitalfond, bilaterala biståndsgivare som ger icke-öronmärkta programstöd samt projektfinansiering. Sverige har varit med och finansierat delar av UNU-WIDER ända sedan starten 1985. Sedan början av 2000-talet har Sidas bidrag varit i form av icke-öronmärkt programstöd. I dagsläget finns tre stora bilaterala givare till UNU-WIDER: Sverige/Sida, UK/dfid och Finland/UD. Under 2019 kommer Norge att ansluta.
UNU-WIDER bedriver forskning, forskarutbildning samt policy- och påverkansarbete inom utvecklingsekonomi. Verksamheten har sin grund i nationalekonomi, men involverar också andra samhällsvetenskapliga discipliner (statsvetenskap, företagsekonomi, sociologi mm). Forskning och policyutveckling bedrivs integrerat.
UNU-WIDER tar fram fleråriga arbetsprogram som tjänar som bas för organisationens aktiviteter och som är utgångspunkt för givargruppens gemensamma finansiering och uppföljning. Arbetsprogrammet 2019-23 har titeln "Transformning economies, states, and societies. Creating and sharing knowledge for development". Arbetsprogrammet bygger vidare på tidigare program, men knyter också tematiskt an till Agenda 2030 för hållbar utveckling, genom att mobilisera policyrelevant forskning och aktiviteter kring ett urval av agendans målområden.
Arbetsprogrammets tre teman syftar till att förstå den omvandling som krävs för en inkluderande och hållbar utveckling: 1) "transforming economies", 2) "transforming states" samt 3) "transforming societies". I arbetsprogrammet identifieras tre områden som ska genomsyra arbetet i sin helhet ("cross-cutting concerns"), nämligen 1) att reducera fragilitet/sårbarhet och risk; 2) att stärka fattiga och marginaliserade människors, inklusive kvinnors och flickors, egenmakt (empowerment); och 3) att bidra till kunskap och kapacitet, särskilt vad gäller policyåtgärder.
Mottagarna av UNU-WIDERs arbete är beslutsfattare i utvecklingsländer, biståndsgivare (development partners) samt den globala forskarvärlden, inklusive FN-systemet. Kommunikationen sker bland annat genom aktiv dialog vid olika ministerier, med lokala grupperingar och i andra sammanhang i direkt anslutning till att forskningsprojekt genomförs och presenteras. Dessutom organiserar UNU-WIDER regelbundet större utvecklingsforskningskonferenser, liksom mer tematiska evenemang. Institutet har en omfattande publiceringsverksamhet (working papers, position papers, policy briefs samt sammanfattande bokvolymer). Organisationen har en relativt ny hemsida där alla egna publikationer finns tillgängliga för alla.
För perioden 2019-23 är förslaget att stödja UNU-WIDER med 8 miljoner svenska kronor per år i fem år, till ett totalt belopp om 40 miljoner kronor. Beloppet innebär en höjning av det årliga bidraget med 1,3 miljoner kronor jämfört med föregående avtalsperiod (2014-18; exklusive den extra tilldelning som organisationen fick 2017 och 2018 om totalt 2,5 miljoner kronor).

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNU-WIDER (World Institute for Development Economics Research) is a research- and training institute founded in 1984 and located in Helsinki, Finland. UNU-WIDER is funded through an endowment fund, bilateral donors providing non-earmarked programme support, and special project support. Sweden has co-funded UNU-WIDER in various forms since its establishment in 1985. Since the early 2000s Sida has provided non-earmarked programme support. At this point there are three major bilateral donors to the UNU-WIDER: Sweden/Sida, UK/DFID and Finland/Ministry of Foreign Affairs. In 2019 Norway will rejoin as donor to the UNU-WIDER.
The activities of UNU-WIDER are research, research training, and policy work and advocacy within development economics. The scientific base is economics, but other social sciences are also included in the work of the institute (political science, mangement studies, sociology etc). Research and policy development activities are integrated.
UNU-WIDER's activities are based on multi-year work programmes, which also serves as a base for the donor group’s joint funding and monitoring activities. The work programme for the 2019-23 period is titled "Transformning economies, states, and societies. Creating and sharing knowledge for development". The programme builds on previous programmes, but in addition connects thematically to the Sustainable Development Goals (Agenda 2030) by mobilizing policy relevant research and other activities for selected goals of the agenda.
The three themes of the work programme aims to understand the transformation required to create inclusive and sustainable development: 1) "Transforming economies", 2) "Transforming states", and 3) "Transforming societies". The work programme identifies three cross-cutting concerns for all research and activities: 1) fragility and risk; 2) empowerment, and 3) knowledge and capacity.
The three target groups for UNU-WIDER's work are decision makers in low-income countries, development partners, and the global research community, including the UN system. Outreach is pursued through active dialogue at relevant ministries, local communities and other directly linked to research projects. Conferences, workshops and seminars for researchers and decision makers are regularly organized. The institute publishes extensively (working papers, position papers, policy briefs and edited books). Apart from scientific publications the institute also produces more policy related material for decision makers and others. All published material is available at the organizastion's web-site (open access).
The proposal is for Sida to support UNU-WIDER for the 2019-23 period by 8 million kronor (SEK), totalling 40 million kronor (SEK) over five years. The amount increases the annual contribution by 1.3 million kronor (SEK) compared to the previous agreement period (2014-18; excluding an extra allocation totalling 2.4 million kronor (SEK) in 2017 and 2018).

title.narrative: SKL - kapacitetsutveckling av lokala guvernorat i Irak (LOGDEVI) 2018-2021
SKL/SALAR Local Governance Development in Iraq (LOGDEVI) 2018-2021

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 SKL har inkommit med en projektansökan till Sida om en budget på 67 300 000 SEK för att implementera "Local Governance Development in Iraq (LOGDEVI)" i Irak, 2018-2021.
Projektet syftar till att bidra till Iraks decentraliseringsreform och förbättring av sociala tjänster i tre guvernorater, Duhok, Diwaniyah och Muthanna med två följande mål: 1) Upprätta politiska ramverk, system och processer som bidrar till effektiv decentralisering i Muthanna och Diwaniyah. Guvernoraterna strävar även efter att fungera som modell för övriga Irak och 2) Integrerad styrning för förbättrad service och barnskydd i Iraks Kurdistan.
SKL kommer att implementera projektet tillsammmans med en lokal organisation, Iraqi Research Foundation for Analysis and Development (IRFAD).

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The project proposal "Local Governance Development in Iraq (LOGDEVI)", 2018-2021 submitted by SALAR has a requested budget of 67 300 000 SEK.
The project aims to contribute to Iraq's decentralisation reform and improving social services in three guvernorates, Duhok, Diwaniyah and Muthanna with the following objectives: 1) Policy framework, systems, and processes are established which are conducive for effective decentralisation in Muthanna and Diwaniyah - and serve as a model for the rest of Iraq och 2) Integrated governance for improved service delivery and child protection in Kurdistan region of Iraq. To implement this project, SALAR will collaborate with a local organisation, Iraqi Research Foundation for Analysis and Development (IRFAD).

The proposed intervention by SALAR is expected to strengthen local governance and service delivery to become more effective, people-centred, and accountable in three governorates in Iraq including the Kurdistan area of Iraq.

title.narrative: Studio Yafa Information and dialogue for social cohesion in Burkina Faso
Studio Yafa "Information och dialog för social sammanhållning i Burkina Faso"

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Fondation Hirondelle, en ideell organisation baserad i Schweiz som arbetar med att stärka oberoende media i framförallt konfliktdrabbade länder, hartill Ambassaden inkommit med en ansökan om stöd till projektet Information och dialog för att stärka den sociala sammanhållningen samt inkluderande och fredligt deltagande i Burkina Faso, under perioden 2019-2021.
Projektet motiveras av de senaste årens omvälvande utveckling i Burkina Faso där en folklig resning 2014 ledde till en demokratisk övergång men också ekonomiska och säkerhetsrelaterade utmaningar, vilket ger starka skäl för Sverige att bidra till en konsolidering av demokratin. Burkina Faso har en mycket ung befolkning, och syftet med insatsen är att ge befolkningen, särskilt de unga, möjlighet att göra sin röst hörd, informera sig och utbyta åsikter samt stimulera dialog, debatt och deltagande i det offentliga livet.
Det övergripande målet med insatsen är att förebygga konflikter, bidra till att stärka fred och social sammanhållning genom information och dialog mellan människor i alla regioner i Burkina Faso. De tre specifika målen är att (1) öka informationen till befolkningen i Burkina Faso, särskilt unga, och göra dem mer aktiva i demokratiska utvecklingsprocesser genom informations- och dialogprogram, (2) stärka och göra den burkinska mediesektorn mer professionell genom utbildning och tekniskt stöd. (3) göra projektet hållbart genom att anta en handlingsplan upprättad av berörda parter.
Strategin är att stärka det burkinska demokratiska systemet och det burkinska samhällsengagemanget, främst hos unga Projektägaren Fondation Hirondelle (FH) ska producera dagliga informationsprogram och multimediadebatter riktade till ungdomar, mestadels flickor och befolkningsgrupper långt ifrån stadskärnor. Det kommer att ske via radioprogram riktade specifikt till dessa områden, både via privata och statliga radioprogram. Journalister från dessa områden samt lokala ungdomsorganisationer (projektpartner) kommer att delta. Projektet är ett försök att förbättra den nationella sociopolitiska situationen. Insatsens budget är 22,8 MSEK varav Sida bidrar med 10 MSEK och Schweiz bidrar med 12,8 MSEK .

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Fondation Hirondelle (FH), a non-profit organisation based in Switzerland working to strengthen independent media in especially conflict-affected countries , has submitted an application for support to the project Studio Yafa/Information and dialogue to strengthen social cohesion and inclusive and peaceful participation in Burkina Faso, for 2019-2021.
The project is motivated by the revolutionary development of recent years in Burkina Faso, where a popular rise in 2014 led to a democratic transition but also economic and security-related challenges, which gives strong reasons for Sweden to contribute to a consolidation of democracy. Burkina Faso has a very young population, and the purpose of the effort is to give the population, especially the young, the opportunity to make their voices heard, inform themselves and exchange views, and stimulate dialogue, debate and participation in public life.
The overall objective of the intervention is to prevent conflicts, contribute strengthen peace and social cohesion through information and dialogue between all peoples and all in all regions of Burkina Faso. The three specific objectives of the intervention are: i) better inform and make more active the population of Burkina Faso, especially young people, in democratic and development processes through information and dialogue programs; ii) strengthen and make the Burkinabé media sector more professional through training and technical support; iii) make the project sustainable by adopting an action plan by the partners involved.
The strategy is to strengthen the Burkinabé democratic system and the citizenship of the Burkinabé, mainly the young and the most marginalized. FH will implement a Studio and produce daily information programs and multimedia debates aimed at young people and populations far from urban centers. This production will be done with community and private radios which touch these areas, journalists coming from these areas and youth local organisations (project partners). The thematics will be in line with the country main challenges and the national socio-political situation.

The overall objective is to contribute to strengthen democracy and citizenship of Burkinabè, mainly young people and the most marginalized. It is also prevent conflicts, contribute to strengthening peace and social cohesion through information and dialogue between all peoples and all in all regions of Burkina Faso. The three specific objectives of the intervention are: i) better inform and make more active the population of Burkina Faso, especially young people, in democratic and development processes through information and dialogue programs; ii) strengthen and make the Burkinabé media sector more professional through training and technical support; iii) make the project sustainable by adopting an action plan by the partners involved. The strategy is to enable people to participate more in democratic processes and in the development of Burkina Faso, mainly the young and the most marginalized. FH will set up a radio studio and produce daily information programs and multimedia debates aimed at young people and the rural population. This production will be done with community and private radios which touch these areas, journalists coming from these areas and youth local organisations (project partners). The themes will be in line with the country main challenges and the national socio-political situation. At the end, Burkinabé democratic system and Burkinabé people, mainly young and marginalized will be strengthened through discussions, exchanges, and at the end that peace and social cohesion are established. The Theory of change outlined by the project is that by providing the population with accurate and adequate information, their capacities capacities for dialogue and conflict resolution are strengthened which enables them to participate in democratic processes och contributing to good governance.The rationale behind supporting people's participation in democratic processes is based on the fact that if young people have access to information about the modalities and opportunities for participating in democracy, if they have the knowledge to make better decisions and exercise their rights, then they will engage actively in the construction of public life, social, economic and political development. The rationale behind contributing to good governance and monitor the government's actions is based on the fact that if the Burkinabe population has access to information and exchange programs that allow citizens, experts, opposition and government to express itself, then the actions and decisions of the government will become more transparent to the citizens and this will increase their confidence in their government. The rationale behind strengthening the processes of dialogue and conflict resolution in Burkina Faso by the fact that if the people, the government, the opposition, the experts, the actors in civil society have a healthy space for dialogue, then they understand and will be able to defuse potential conflicts. And if the audience, people perceive that it is possible for groups of conflict prevention to discuss their issues peacefully, then a culture of peace that promotes peaceful conflict resolution will be strengthened. Finally, the project aims to consolidate the media sector, as key to the success of the three previous stages of the theory of change: If Burkina Faso's media sector is strengthened and professionalized thanks to training and technical support, then the Burkinabe media will be better able to assume their mission and in particular to give the floor and respond to the information needs of young people in Burkina Faso.

description.narrative: The Project's ambition was that by the end of the first year, the productions broadcast on radio and television would be accessible to approximately 20% of the Burkinabè population, in all regions of the country. This objective during the 14 months (November 2018-December 2019) of Studio Yafa's implementation is largely achieved. Inded, more than 60% of the urbain and rural population can receive information from Studio Yafa. The young people who listen and follow Studio Yafa's broadcasts in many languages (Dioula, French, Fulfuldé, Gulmencema and Mooré) are aware of the topics covered and that their participation in public debate is increased thanks to the space for dialogue offered during outdoor debates. The majority of its listeners find that the programs are reliable and of quality and the treatment of the subjects of the programs leads the young people to become aware of their well-being. Outcome 1: The Burkinabe population, and especially young people, are better informed and more active in democratic and development processes thanks to information and dialogue programs Unanimously in the various localities, the information from Studio Yafa is considered reliable by the respondents to the focus groups organized by ICI a study firm and to a mini survey carried out in partnership with Viamo, our distribution partner via telephony. Whether in the case of mini-mags or talk shows, the quality of the shows is highly appreciated. A considerable part of those polled also believe that these programs should be the subject of wider distribution and more effective promotion to listeners: “These emissions are very good, because after listening you can decide to change. We want Studio Yafa to advertise more so that we can listen to their work more often. We will take the opportunity to invite our loved ones to listen to the studio's broadcasts. "(Testimony of a woman met in Dédougou during the investigation conducted by ICI, December 2019). Other testimonies, collected by the directors of the partner radio stations from young listeners, indicate that the treatment of the subjects of the programs leads "young people to an awareness for their well-being". Studio Yafa's 15 partner radios (Unalfa) find the programs produced interesting for young people in their community. Finally, a mini survey carried out as part of the partnership with Viamo made it possible to assess the appreciation of Orange telephone subscribers compared to Yafa's mini-mags. 1,450 people answered the questionnaire between April 11 and June 11. The results are positive, with 53% of respondents finding Yafa's magazine great; 27%: very good; 11%: it works and 9%: bad The results of the outcome 1 is achieved throught results from outputs: Output 1: An audio and video production studio which respects professional and ethical journalism rules is created. - One (1) operational local law structure which strictly respects journalistic rules has been created: Studio Yafa- - Studio Yafa's production team is recruited (23 Burkinabè employees, including 14 men and 9 women, on average 33 years old) - An audio and video production studio that respects professional and ethical journalism rules has been created - Studio Yafa is now the only professional audio and video production studio dedicated to young people that respects the professional and ethical rules of journalism, and which works with a network of 25 Burkinabè radio stations across the country Output 2: A greater supply of information that allows the Burkinabè population, especially young people, to understand the important issues in their lives and to be active citizens is proposed. The results of the 1st studies and survey of listeners show that Studio Yafa's information offer is relevant for young people. The topics covered are varied, while taking into account the main concerns of young people, namely employment and social cohesion: - Several media contents have been developed in five languages ??(Dioula, French, Fulfuldé, Gulmencema and Mooré). - 5 daily mini-magazines of 3 min in 5 languages - Between 1 to 2.5 min of video in French, - Daily posts on Facebook and Twitter pages - Daily feed to Studio Yafa's website. Output 3: Media spaces and platforms created for young Burkinabe allow them to make their voices and concerns heard, as well as to dialogue with political leaders and decision-makers The production of media programs and content has contributed to enriching the information offer for young people in the country as well as providing them with spaces for dialogue. - The Studio's broadcasts through the 25 partner radio stations covered 75% of the territory, giving access to information to a majority of Burkinabé. - 33 weekly programs in French of 45 minutes "Ya'Débat" were produced and broadcast. - 31% of women under 35 participated in the "Ya'Débat" - several hundred young Burkinabè participated in 4 outdoor public debates of 45min were organized in Bobo-Dioulasso, Léo and Tenkodogo Output 5: Access to information and dialogue programs via a network of Burkinabè media partners throughout the country and on the web is improved. - Partnership was signed with UNALFA, UBESTV. - 25 partner radios benefit from training and internship at the studio - Studio Yafa covers approximately 75% of the territory, thus giving access to information to a majority of the Burkinabè population. - 50% of listeners follow the Studio's radio programs in the regions. - 12,000 Facebook subscribers under 35, 380 Tweeter followers follow the programs - 500 videos on average per month are viewed on Facebook and 1,000 on Youtube. - Numerous audio programs, articles, photos and videos are posted daily and weekly on the website studioyafa.org - The Studio's audience increased thanks to the successful partnership with Viamo which made it possible to increase the distribution of mini-mags via telephony Outcome 2: The Burkinabè media sector is strengthened and more professional thanks to training and technical support Output 6: The editorial and managerial capacities of partner radio stations are strengthened - 15 journalists (4 women and 11 men aged 33) were trained in good journalistic practices - 4 journalists-trainees of correspondents and benefit from remote coaching - 22 Directors and representatives of 18 radio stations received training on revenue generation and monetization of digital content Output 7: The technical capacities of partner radio stations are strengthened: A kit of reports and a computer given to 15 partner radio stations Output 8: The training offer for Burkinabè students is strengthened: - Two students did an immersion of 2 months each at Studio Yafa. One will write a dissertation on information for young people at Studio Yafa; the other on the impact of radio productions on youth. These dissertations will enrich the studio's impact work in the second half of 2020. - Training for 20 young high school students in 1st and Terminal to introduce them to the basics of radio journalism (in collaboration with Goethe Institue)
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Rädda Barnen, utbildning i konflikt Afghanistan, 2018-2021
Save the Children, Education in Emergencies Afghanistan, 2018-2021

description.narrative:
Denna insats syftar till att erbjuda utbildning och stöd till återvändande, internflyktingar, barn med funktionshinder samt andra utsatta grupper i tre provinser.
Programmets övergripande mål är att öka tillgången till inkluderande utbildning av god kvalitet och att skapa en säker lärandemiljö för de pojkar och flickor i åldern 5-15 år som drabbats av konflikter och katastrofer. Projektet beräknas erbjuda 7 600 barn (50% flickor) grundskoleutbildning (årskurs 1 till 3) och 5 600 barn (50% flickor) en ettårig förskoleutbildning.
Projektets prioriterade verksamhetsområden är följande: (1) utbildning av flickor, internflyktingar, återvändande barn samt barn i utsatta samhällen; (2) stödja registrering och inkludering av barn i det formella skolsystemet; (3) utöka alternativa utbildningsformer (Community Based Education) och utbildning i konfliktområden; och (4) skapa skydd för utsatta barn samt bidra till ökad tillgång på vatten och sanitetsanrättningar i anslutning till skolan.
Denna insats är högst relevant utifrån den svenska strategin för utvecklingssamarbete med Afghanistan 2014-2019 avseende tillgång till förbättrad skolgång för flickor och pojkar och gör det möjligt för fler flickor och pojkar att slutföra sin skolgång. Insatsen bidrar också till ökad respekt för de mänskliga rättigheterna, med särskild inriktning på barnens möjligheter att åtnjuta sina mänskliga rättigheter samt strategiresultatet att förstärka kapaciteten inom offentliga institutioner när det gäller tillhandahållande av grundläggande samhällstjänster.
Save the Children International Afghanistan (SCI-A) är den främsta implementeraren av programmet och kommer att arbeta tillsammans med en lokal partner, Welfare Association for the Development of Afghanistan (WADAN). Rädda Barnen Sverige är Sidas avtalspartner avseende denna insats.
Sida bidrar med 24 MSEK för genomförandet av projektet under perioden från december 2018 till maj 2020.

The proposed intervention aims to provide integrated community-based education and child protection services for returnees, Internally Displace Persons, vulnerable host communities, and children with disabilities in three provinces.
The overall objective of the programme is to improve the access to inclusive quality education in emergencies, and provide a safe learning environment for conflict affected boys and girls aged from 5 to 15 years old in three provinces. The intervention will target 7,600 children (50% girls) within primary education (grade 1 to grade 3) and 5,600 children (50% girls) within a one-year community-based pre-school education in the three considered geographical areas.
The priority areas of the project are: (1) focus on education of girls, vulnerable Host Communities (HC), Internally Displaced People (IDP) and returnee children; (2) support enrolment of HC, IDP and returnee children into formal schools; and (3) expand Community Based Education (CBE) and Education in Emergency (EiE) Classes; (4) Child Protection and WASH services.
This intervention is highly relevant according to the Results strategy for Sweden’s international development cooperation with Afghanistan, 2014–2019 regarding access to improved schooling for girls and boys and making it possible for more girls and boys to complete their schooling. It is also related to results on strengthened respect for human rights, with particular focus on the opportunities of children to enjoy their human rights, and the result on strengthened capacity of public institutions to provide basic services in Afghanistan.
Save the Children International Afghanistan (SCI-A) is the main implementer of the pogramme and will work with a local partner, Welfare Association for the Development of Afghanistan (WADAN). Save the Children Sweden is Sida's contract partner for this contribution.
Sida supports the intervention by providing 24 MSEK for the implementation of the project during the period from December 2018 to May 2020.

The proposed project aims to provide integrated community-based education and child protection services for returnees (documented and undocumented), Internally Displaced Persons (conflict and natural disaster affected), vulnerable host communities, and children with disabilities in Kabul, Balkh and Jawzjan Provinces. The overall objective of the programme is to improve the access to quality and inclusive education in emergencies, and provide a safe learning environment for conflict affected girls and boys aged from 5 to 15 years in three provinces. The total number of people targeted through this intervention is more than 43,000 (29,000 girls and boys and 14,000 women and men, i.e. teachers, parents, community members and others). The expected results are as follows: 1. Increased access to quality basic education for Internally Displaced Persons (IDP), returnee and host community boys and girls. 2. A child-friendly, protective and inclusive environment is created for emergency-affected boys and girls. 3. Continuity of Education for emergency-affected girls and boys is increased. 4. Quality of learning for emergency-affected girls and boys is improved. A robust child protection component is integrated into the intervention, supporting children to overcome their trauma, reintegrate into the community and return to normalcy. A Logical Framework has been developed as an annex to the proposal. Some of the stated outputs are as follows: Enhancing capacity of School Management Committees/Shuras and School Councils to seek community support for the enrollment of boys and girls in Community Based Education (CBE)/Education in Emergencies (EiE) classes; provision of teaching and learning kits; access to gender friendly wash facilities; establishment of Child Friendly Spaces where CBE classes have been established; provision of psychosocial trainings along with the delivery of psychosocial first aid; and providing supplies to and training of hub-school teachers on child friendly gender sensitive and inclusive teaching methodologies. Adjustment PHASE II and Corona Outbreak By the time of the COVID 19 outbreak, Save the Children was fairly much in phase with the planned activities. However, the Corona virus has definitely changed the methods, means and challenges working in Afghanistan in many ways. If this situation will remain during 2021 or not, is hard to assess. Nevertheless, the long term consequences of the COVID 19 will have long terms effects on the country. Although there are a number of technical or methodological changes taken to combat the problems causued by the Pandemia, the four expected results are still as valid as previously. Consequently the Since the schools have been closed for a period, Save the Children and other actors have developed methods to provide education by Internet, TV and Radio instead of cancelled classes. Teachers are given teacher training kits to support them by self-learning and the provision of Water and Sanitation facilities in schools are to be increased as this also is a measure to minize the effects of the Corona Pandemia. Due to the Covid Pandemia there is an improved cooperation between the MoE, Save the Children and the member organizations of the EiE working group - being a result that could facilitate the development of the Afghanistan Education system in a long-term perspective.As for the new long distance means developed to provide learning kits, education by radio and other methods developed currently, would provide better alternatives for presumptive pupils in Emergency or conflict areas even in the future.

participating-org.narrative: Save the Children - donor country office

tag.narrative: 4.1 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
4.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar fullbordar avgiftsfri och likvärdig grundskole- och gymnasieutbildning av god kvalitet som leder till relevanta och ändamålsenliga kunskaper.

4.5 - By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.

4.5 - Senast 2030 avskaffa skillnaderna mellan könen inom utbildningsområdet och säkerställa lika tillgång till utbildning och yrkesutbildning på alla nivåer för utsatta personer, inklusive personer med funktionsnedsättning, ursprungsfolk och barn som lever under utsatta förhållanden.

4.7 - By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and non-violence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture’s contribution to sustainable development.

4.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla studerande får de kunskaper och färdigheter som behövs för att främja en hållbar utveckling, bland annat genom utbildning för hållbar utveckling och hållbara livsstilar, mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet, främjande av en kultur av fred, icke-våld och globalt medborgarskap samt värdesättande av kulturell mångfald och kulturens bidrag till hållbar utveckling.

description.narrative: During the first 13th month period, Save the Children Sweden (SCS), Save the Children International-Afghanistan (SCI-A) and Partner WADAN managed to start up all the pre-planned activities in line with plan, although in some cases a bit later than anticipated. During this period: - Project staff and Community Mobilizers have been recruited and the project has been introduced to Provincial Education Departments and District Education Departments in Kabul, Balkh and Jawzjan provinces. - 218 Community Based Education (CBE) teachers have been recruited and provided with trainings on modern teaching methodologies as well as on psychosocial support (PSS). - 218 CBE classes, 94 preschool classes and 66 Child Friendly Spaces (CFS) have been established. - Approximately 7,600 children (including more than 4 000 girls) have completed grade 1 while pre-school children will be transitioned into grade 1 in the beginning of 2020. More than 1,000 children participated in the Child Friendly Spaces (CFS) and will in the upcoming cycle be transferred to Community Based Education. In certain areas there are no formal education buildings for the enrollment of children to grade 1, thus classes will take place in community buildings or homes. In 2020, due to national Covid-19 restrictions, face-to-face activities in Afghanistan were suspended from March to September 2020. This meant that several planned activities were postponed, altered, or cancelled. To ensure continued project implementation, SCS worked with the Ministry of Education (MoE) to refine its strategy and developed alternative learning pathways, including the following modalities: 1) home based self-learning program; 2) distance learning program through television and radio; and 3) reduced sizing of classes (i.e. 6-8 students per class), along with increased hygiene and disinfection standard operating procedures. Until September 2020: - 95% of 7,671 students (4,361 girls and 3,310 boys) have been benefitted through home-based learning modality. - Remote case identification and referral mechanism was established and practiced during the pandemic. Project staff were regularly contacting teachers and community education councils and asking them about student’s health status and child protection risks associated to children especially child labor. A total of 222 cases (106 boys and 116 girls) have been referred so far. - SCI-A is providing education to 80 children with hearing and visual impairment under the Joyful Learning project.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Rädda Barnen, utbildning i konflikt Afghanistan, 2018-2021
Save the Children, Education in Emergencies Afghanistan, 2018-2021

description.narrative:
Denna insats syftar till att erbjuda utbildning och stöd till återvändande, internflyktingar, barn med funktionshinder samt andra utsatta grupper i tre provinser.
Programmets övergripande mål är att öka tillgången till inkluderande utbildning av god kvalitet och att skapa en säker lärandemiljö för de pojkar och flickor i åldern 5-15 år som drabbats av konflikter och katastrofer. Projektet beräknas erbjuda 7 600 barn (50% flickor) grundskoleutbildning (årskurs 1 till 3) och 5 600 barn (50% flickor) en ettårig förskoleutbildning.

Denna insats är högst relevant utifrån den svenska strategin för utvecklingssamarbete med Afghanistan 2014-2019 avseende tillgång till förbättrad skolgång för flickor och pojkar och gör det möjligt för fler flickor och pojkar att slutföra sin skolgång. Insatsen bidrar också till ökad respekt för de mänskliga rättigheterna, med särskild inriktning på barnens möjligheter att åtnjuta sina mänskliga rättigheter samt strategiresultatet att förstärka kapaciteten inom offentliga institutioner när det gäller tillhandahållande av grundläggande samhällstjänster.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Initiative Africa 2018-2023, Making Change Happen 2 - Business for Peace
COVID-19 Initiative Africa 2018-2023, Making Change Happen 2 - Business for Peace

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Insatsens övergripande mål är att bidra till ökad jämställdhet i Etiopien. Detta planerar man göra genom att fokusera på en av de underliggande orsakerna till bristande jämställdhet i landet, nämligen våld mot kvinnor. Insatsen tar kvinnan/flickan i centrum och fokuserar insatsen på institutioner som en flicka/kvinna passerar i livet samt institutioner som kan ha en stor katalytisk effekt. Det rör sig om skolan, arbetslivet och media.
Insatsen har valt ut ett antal skolor, privata företag, offentliga institutioner och mediahus inom vilket arbetet ska pågå. Media spelar en roll som både budbärare och arbetplats. Insatsen ska genomföras i partnership med Initiative Africa som är Ambassadens avtalspart, samt Unicef och UNFPA. Insatsen finansieras gemensamt av Ambassaden/Sida, Packard Foundation och Austria Aid.
Det föreslås att Ambassaden finansierar insatsen med ett belopp om SEK 11 390 000 under perioden juli 2018- juni 2021.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The overall objective of the intervention is to strenghten gender equality in Ethiopia. The intervention will contrbute to that by addressing some of the underlying causes to gender inequality in the country; gender based violence. The intervention puts the woman/girl in the centre and will try to address violence in instituions and places where a woman/girl moves around through life and by including institution that may have positive catalytic effect on gender equality. Those are schools, workplaces and the media.
The agreement partner to the Embassy is Initiative Africa, a well known NGO with whom the Embassy has worked with before. The intervention will be jointly funded by Sweden, Packard Foundation and Austria Aid. It is proposed that Sweden contributes with an amount of SEK 11 390 000 for July 2018- Juni 2021.

The project aims to bridge the gap between civics and peace building activities especially involving the private sector. It takes a two-pronged approach that includes: (a) development of several civic education programs as a tool for peace-building; and(b) enhancement of capacity of business to handle complex conflict subject matter, especially in relation to social inequality and justice. The following objectives are identified:1. To mobilize the business community to engage in peace-building and conflict resolution actions and activities.2. Through corporate social responsibility to maintain support for effective peace building and inclusive coordination amongst Government, private sector, media actors and civil society.3. To respond to concrete challenges and opportunities to build a peaceful and just Ethiopia through civic education, training, internship and apprenticeship activities.

sector.narrative: Ending violence against women and girls

tag.narrative: 5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.
5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer

description.narrative: During 2019, Initiative Africa with it's Making Change Happen project, was able to target six regional states of Ethiopia. As stated above, IA was able to accomplish its goals working with secondary and tertiary schools, media houses, local governments, CSOs and business people. Out of the achieved results, the development of the two strategic tools to implement gender mainstreaming in the media sector as well as the School Violence Index tool being implemented in some 96 schools across the nation come at the top. The baseline assessment report that was carried out in companies operational plan and program cycle and the extent of which these plans had gender perspective was also one of the achieved results. Other achievements focus on various trainings and capacity building of youth health and sports club for young girls. The civic engagement aspect was also another area in which visible achievements could be seen, especially in light of the 25 discussion forums held in five universities of the country. Another successful result is the communication results. IA has been able to produce and broadcast high quality short videos in partnership with known media houses in the country as well as publishing articles including cartoon in some of the known newspaper and magazines circulating nationwide. School clubs run by students have benefited from capacity building initiatives as well as communication tools for the fight against bullying, gender based violence and for targeted SRH related messaging.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The rights of LGBTIQ persons and women's and girls' access to SRHR are protected in Guatemalan legislation and in international agreements entered into by the country. Despite this, LGBTIQ persons are subjected to violations, violence and discrimination. Similarly, girls and women's sexual and reproductive rights are violated, in practice, access to sexual and reproductive health is limited (SRHR).
The programme "Network for diversity and inclusion in Guatemala" will be implemented by HIVOS, an international civil society organisation with headquarters in the Netherlands, in collaboration with eight partner organisations. The programme has a three-fold purpose: • Through influence, accountability, constructive proposals and cooperation, support state institutions to better guarantee statutory rights, focusing on the SRHR and the judiciary's ability to act against violations, violence and discrimination (including labor law). • To improve access to comprehensive sexual education in accordance with national laws and strategies. • Strengthening civil society organisations that work for these rights and their ability to create networks that work towards common goals.
The Swedish grant to the program, SEK 32 million, will help carry out communication work, produce research and evidence-based policy proposals, educate and inform, as well as provide legal and psychological support to persons who have been violated. Strengthening the systems, administration and internal democracy of local organisations is another important element.
The fact that the programme encompasses both SRHR, LGBTIQ rights, women's and girls 'empowerment, and masculinity is a new approach that can increase the effects of the various organisations' activities and also open up to broader alliances between organisations that have not traditionally collaborated.
The eight partner organisations have a presence in four of Guatemala's 17 regions, both the metropolitan region, and regions with a high proportion of indigenous peoples, who are particularly hard hit by maternal mortality, sexual violence and teenage pregnancies.
Dialogue and strategic communication will be coordinated with the Netherlands Embassy in Costa Rica, which funds a regional HIVOS programme on the same theme.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 HBTIQ-personers rättigheter och kvinnors och flickors tillgång till SRHR skyddas i Guatemalas lagstiftning och i internationella överenskommelser som landet ingått. Trots detta utsätts HBTIQ-personer för kränkningar, våld och diskriminering. Likaså kränks flickor och kvinnors sexuella och reproduktiva rättigheter, tillgången till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa är i praktiken begränsad (SRHR).
Programmet ”Nätverk för mångfald och inkludering i Guatemala” kommer att genomföras av HIVOS, en internationell civilsamhällsorganisation med huvudkontor i Nederländerna, i samarbete med åtta partnerorganisationer. Programmet har ett trefaldigt syfte: • Att genom påverkan, ansvarsutkrävande, konstruktiva förslag och samarbete stödja statliga institutioner att i högre grad garantera lagstadgade rättigheter, med fokus på SRHR och rättsväsendets förmåga att agera mot kränkningar, våld och diskriminering (inklusive arbetsrättslig sådan). • Att förbättra tillgången till allsidig sexualundervisning i enlighet med nationella lagar och strategier. • Att stärka civilsamhällsorganisationer som verkar för dessa rättigheter och deras förmåga att skapa nätverk som arbetar mot gemensamma mål.
Det svenska bidraget till programmet, 32 miljoner kronor, kommer att bidra till att bedriva kommunikationsarbete, ta fram forskning och evidensbaserade policyförslag, utbilda och informera, samt ge rättsligt och psykologiskt stöd åt personer som fått sina rättigheter kränkta. Att stärka de lokala organisationernas system, förvaltning och interndemokrati är ett annat viktigt inslag.
Att programmet omfattar både SRHR, HBTIQ-rättigheter, kvinnors och flickors egenmakt, samt maskulinitet är ett nytt grepp som kan öka effekterna av de olika organisationernas verksamhet och dessutom öppna upp för bredare allianser mellan organisationer som traditionellt inte samarbetat.
De åtta partnerorganisationer har närvaro i fyra av Guatemalas 17 regioner, både huvudstadsregionen, och regioner med en hög andel urfolk och som drabbas särskilt hårt av mödradödlighet, sexuellt våld och tonårsgraviditeter.
Dialog och strategisk kommunikation kommer att samordnas med Nederländernas ambassad i Costa Rica, som finansierar ett regionalt HIVOS-program på samma tema.

The programme “Network for diversity and inclusion” will be implemented by Hivos and eight local partner organisations during a four-year-long period. The Swedish contribution to the project is SEK 32 000 000. Hivos is responsible for forwarding the funds to the third-party organisations along with providing administrative, technical and strategic support. There are two specific objectives of the programme related to achievements in societal change, and one strategic objective related to strenghtening of civil society. The first objective is to support the state and its institutions in assuming their role as duty bearers guaranteeing the citizens' rights as established in national and international law, particularly in sexual and reproductive health rights with a strong focus on LGBTIQ-rights, access to justice and labour rights. The second objective is to guarantee girls, boys, adolescents and youth an effective access to comprehensive sexual education. The third objective is to strengthen the third-party organisations to make them more independent and able to act in alliances with other civil society organisation to achieve their goals.

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative: The programme Guatediversa initiated in November 2019 and no results have been reported on yet. During this first project year Hivos has entered into agreements with the eight local partner organisations and worked on the annual plan jointly. In June 2020 Sida approved a minor adjustment in the annual plan due to Covid-19. Some activities have been postponed or changed into virtual activities. An agreement amendment was signed in June 2020 for an additional partner organisation to be included for 12 months in the programme, the Guatemalan Human Rights Ombudsman. Hivos will channel MSEK 5 to the Ombudsman office for special activities related to the Covid crisis. Annual reporting for 2020 is due in April 2021.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The rights of LGBTIQ persons and women's and girls' access to SRHR are protected in Guatemalan legislation and in international agreements entered into by the country. Despite this, LGBTIQ persons are subjected to violations, violence and discrimination. Similarly, girls and women's sexual and reproductive rights are violated, in practice, access to sexual and reproductive health is limited (SRHR).
The programme "Network for diversity and inclusion in Guatemala" will be implemented by HIVOS, an international civil society organisation with headquarters in the Netherlands, in collaboration with eight partner organisations. The programme has a three-fold purpose: • Through influence, accountability, constructive proposals and cooperation, support state institutions to better guarantee statutory rights, focusing on the SRHR and the judiciary's ability to act against violations, violence and discrimination (including labor law). • To improve access to comprehensive sexual education in accordance with national laws and strategies. • Strengthening civil society organisations that work for these rights and their ability to create networks that work towards common goals.
The Swedish grant to the program, SEK 32 million, will help carry out communication work, produce research and evidence-based policy proposals, educate and inform, as well as provide legal and psychological support to persons who have been violated. Strengthening the systems, administration and internal democracy of local organisations is another important element.
The fact that the programme encompasses both SRHR, LGBTIQ rights, women's and girls 'empowerment, and masculinity is a new approach that can increase the effects of the various organisations' activities and also open up to broader alliances between organisations that have not traditionally collaborated.
The eight partner organisations have a presence in four of Guatemala's 17 regions, both the metropolitan region, and regions with a high proportion of indigenous peoples, who are particularly hard hit by maternal mortality, sexual violence and teenage pregnancies.
Dialogue and strategic communication will be coordinated with the Netherlands Embassy in Costa Rica, which funds a regional HIVOS programme on the same theme.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 HBTIQ-personers rättigheter och kvinnors och flickors tillgång till SRHR skyddas i Guatemalas lagstiftning och i internationella överenskommelser som landet ingått. Trots detta utsätts HBTIQ-personer för kränkningar, våld och diskriminering. Likaså kränks flickor och kvinnors sexuella och reproduktiva rättigheter, tillgången till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa är i praktiken begränsad (SRHR).
Programmet ”Nätverk för mångfald och inkludering i Guatemala” kommer att genomföras av HIVOS, en internationell civilsamhällsorganisation med huvudkontor i Nederländerna, i samarbete med åtta partnerorganisationer. Programmet har ett trefaldigt syfte: • Att genom påverkan, ansvarsutkrävande, konstruktiva förslag och samarbete stödja statliga institutioner att i högre grad garantera lagstadgade rättigheter, med fokus på SRHR och rättsväsendets förmåga att agera mot kränkningar, våld och diskriminering (inklusive arbetsrättslig sådan). • Att förbättra tillgången till allsidig sexualundervisning i enlighet med nationella lagar och strategier. • Att stärka civilsamhällsorganisationer som verkar för dessa rättigheter och deras förmåga att skapa nätverk som arbetar mot gemensamma mål.
Det svenska bidraget till programmet, 32 miljoner kronor, kommer att bidra till att bedriva kommunikationsarbete, ta fram forskning och evidensbaserade policyförslag, utbilda och informera, samt ge rättsligt och psykologiskt stöd åt personer som fått sina rättigheter kränkta. Att stärka de lokala organisationernas system, förvaltning och interndemokrati är ett annat viktigt inslag.
Att programmet omfattar både SRHR, HBTIQ-rättigheter, kvinnors och flickors egenmakt, samt maskulinitet är ett nytt grepp som kan öka effekterna av de olika organisationernas verksamhet och dessutom öppna upp för bredare allianser mellan organisationer som traditionellt inte samarbetat.
De åtta partnerorganisationer har närvaro i fyra av Guatemalas 17 regioner, både huvudstadsregionen, och regioner med en hög andel urfolk och som drabbas särskilt hårt av mödradödlighet, sexuellt våld och tonårsgraviditeter.
Dialog och strategisk kommunikation kommer att samordnas med Nederländernas ambassad i Costa Rica, som finansierar ett regionalt HIVOS-program på samma tema.

The programme “Network for diversity and inclusion” will be implemented by Hivos and eight local partner organisations during a four-year-long period. The Swedish contribution to the project is SEK 32 000 000. Hivos is responsible for forwarding the funds to the third-party organisations along with providing administrative, technical and strategic support. There are two specific objectives of the programme related to achievements in societal change, and one strategic objective related to strenghtening of civil society. The first objective is to support the state and its institutions in assuming their role as duty bearers guaranteeing the citizens' rights as established in national and international law, particularly in sexual and reproductive health rights with a strong focus on LGBTIQ-rights, access to justice and labour rights. The second objective is to guarantee girls, boys, adolescents and youth an effective access to comprehensive sexual education. The third objective is to strengthen the third-party organisations to make them more independent and able to act in alliances with other civil society organisation to achieve their goals.

5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

title.narrative: COVID-19 MADRE, Kvinnor fred och säkerhet 2018-2021

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 MADRE är en internationell civilsamhällesorganisation baserad i USA. MADRE arbetar i solidaritet med lokala kvinnoledda organisation i konflikt- och krigsområden för att främja social rättvisa och kvinnors fulla deltagande i konfliktlösning och fredsbyggande. För närvarande arbetar MADRE i Iraq, Syrien, Palestina, Kenya, Sudan, Nicaragua, Guatemala, Haiti, DRK och Colombia. MADRE använder en rad olika strategier, exempelvis juridiskt påverkansarbete, vidareförmedling av medel till lokala partners, humanitärt stöd, kapacitetsuppbyggnad och mobilisering av kvinnoorganisationer och aktivister. MADRE är dessutom en stark röst i utformningen av den internationella dialogen och normativ ram kring Kvinnor fred och säkerhet i nära samarbete med både internationella och nationella partner samt genom att stödja det praktiska genomförandet av de centrala delarna i dagordningen på nationell nivå.
MADRE planerar att expandera sin verksamhet under nästa strategiperiod och budgetprojiceringen för åren 2018/19, 2019/20, 2020/21 är totalt motsvarande ca 200 000 000 kronor, varav ca 28% är beräknat till vidareförmedling till lokala partners. Andra givare består främst av amerikanska privata stiftelser och individuella givare.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 MADRE is an international civil society organization based in the United States. MADRE works in solidarity with local women-led organization in areas and countries affected by conflict and war to promote social justice and women's full participation in conflict resolution and peace building. Currently, MADRE is working in Iraq, Syria, Palestine, Kenya, Sudan, Nicaragua, Guatemala, Haiti, DRC and Colombia. MADRE uses a variety of strategies, such as legal advocacy work, forwarding of funds to local partners, humanitarian support, capacity building and mobilization of women's organizations and activists. MADRE is also a strong voice in the design of the international dialogue and normative framework for Women's Peace and Security in close cooperation with both international and national partners as well as by supporting the practical implementation of the central parts of the agenda at national level.
MADRE plans to expand its operations during the next strategic period and budget projection for 2018/19, 2019/20, 2020/21 is a total of approximately SEK 200,000,000, of which about 28% is planned to be forwarded to local partners. Other donors mainly consist of US private foundations and individual donors.

The MADRE Strategy for 2018-22 presents 3 interlinked goals; 1) Women at the margin leads, meaning women and girls who are excluded from power and representation in their societies will gain capacities, resources and access to policy making and other centers of power; 2) Policies and attitudes change, meaning new policies at local, national and global level to uphold women’s rights and change of attitudes and social norms to reflect priorities of women at the margin; 3) Progressive movements gain power, meaning movements that are critical to advancing social change for social justice and gender equality are strengthened and play leadership roles in global movements. MADRE seeks to assist community based and women led grassroots organisations to address gendered root causes of conflict, the effect of disasters and their aftermath by advancing human rights and social justice and to meet critical needs in the communities. MADRE furthermore recognizes the disproportionate impact of conflict on women and girls, and the need to ensure their active participation in conflict resolution and peace building to ensure both inclusive society and sustainable peace. MADRE specifically seeks to prioritize marginalized groups, such as young women and girls of indigenous or Afro-descendant origin or with disablities and LGBTIQ people. MADRE also directly link conflict and fragility to climate change and environmental deterioration, and the potential gendered consequences in the communities. MADRE argues that human rights obligations and social justice can be strengthened in conflict and fragile contexts by meeting the urgent community needs through programs that asserts women’s rights and leadership, including sustaining the environment; support the participation, agency and voice of grassroots women in a rage of social movement and policy making spaces; strengthen the exchange of ideas and strategies within and across social movements and diverse communities of activists; improve policies at all levels of governance by using the human rights framework to institutionalize social movement demands; and change and challenge social norms and attitudes using legal advocacy combined with community mobilization and organizing. MADRE builds on more than 35 years of institutional expertise and practical experience from 25 countries. MADRE is a leading international women’s rights organisation, and distinguishes itself by standing at the intersection of the movements for global peace, economic, environmental and climate justice, women’s and LGBTIQ rights, sexual rights and Indigenous and Afro-descendant rights.

tag.narrative: 16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
